document.title: Toric data and Killing forms on homogeneous Sasaki-Einstein manifold T1,1

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: Throughout this paper we investigate the complex structure of the conifold ⁢C(T1,1) basically making use of the interplay between symplectic and complex approaches of the Kähler toric manifolds. The description of the Calabi-Yau manifold ⁢C(T1,1) using toric data allows us to write explicitly the complex coordinates and apply standard methods for extracting special Killing forms on the base manifold. As an outcome, we obtain the complete set of special Killing forms on the five-dimensional Sasaki-Einstein space T1,1.

para.p: 1]Vladimir Slesarvlslesar@central.ucv.ro 2]Mihai Visinescumvisin@theory.nipne.ro 3,4]Gabriel Eduard Vîlcugvilcu@upg-ploiesti.rogvilcu@gta.math.unibuc.ro \affil[1]Department of Mathematics, University of Craiova,
Str. Al.I. Cuza, Nr. 13, Craiova 200585, Romania \affil[2]Department of Theoretical Physics,
National Institute for Physics and Nuclear Engineering,
Magurele, P.O.Box M.G.-6, Romania \affil[3]Department of Cybernetics and Economic Informatics,
Petroleum-Gas University of Ploieşti,
Bd. Bucureşti, Nr. 39, Ploieşti 100680, Romania \affil[4]Faculty of Mathematics and Computer Science,
Research Center in Geometry, Topology and Algebra,
University of Bucharest, Str. Academiei, Nr. 14, Sector 1, Bucharest 060042, Romania

Symmetries are widely used as a useful tool in modeling physical systems. The ordinary symmetries are associated with isometries, that are spacetime diffeomorphisms that leave the metric invariant. A one-parameter continuous isometry is connected with a Killing vector field. An extension of the Killing vector fields is represented by conformal Killing vector fields [23] with flows preserving a given class of metrics.

However, it has been proved that the investigation of symmetries in the whole phase space of a system is exceedingly useful. Such transformations of the whole phase space for which the dynamics of the system is left invariant are often referred as hidden symmetries. The hidden symmetries of curved manifolds are represented by Killing tensors and Killing-Yano tensors. Thanks to such symmetries many complicated physical problems become tractable taking into account that the equation of motion are separable and integrable. Analogously, conformal Killing-Yano tensors are associated with conserved quantities along null geodesics and integrability of massless field equations.

The purpose of this paper is to present a method to construct Killing forms on toric Sasaki-Einstein manifolds. We exemplify the procedure in the case of the five-dimensional homogeneous Sasaki-Einstein manifold T1,1.

Until recently the only explicitly known non-trivial Sasaki-Einstein metric in dimension five was T1,1 [5]. The five-dimensional manifolds Tp,q which are the coset spaces ⁢/(⁢×⁢SU(2)SU(2))U(1) have been considered by Romans [16] in the context of Kaluza-Klein supergravity. Romans found that for p=q=1 the compactification preserves 8 supersymmetries, while for other p and q all supersymmetries are broken.
In light of the ⁢/⁢AdSCFT correspondence the ×⁢AdS5T1,1 model of [10] is the first example of a supersymmetric holographic theory based on a compact manifold which is not locally S5.

The approach we take in order to achieve our goal basically relies on the interplay between symplectic and complex coordinates on toric manifolds [13, 1]. In our particular case, this description of the conifold is slightly different from [11, 8], when the geometric features of the conifold are mainly exhibited. In turn, our approach enable us to use the correspondence between special Killing forms and parallel forms on the metric cone which was introduced by Semmelmann [18]. For more details concerning this method in the case of toric manifolds we refer to [22, 20].

The paper is organized in the following manner: In the second Section we introduces the main concepts and technical tools we use in the rest of the paper. We also give the necessary preliminaries regarding the special Killing forms, toric Sasaki-Einstein manifolds and the way their Calabi-Yau cones spaces can be regarded as complex manifolds. In Section 3 we apply these results constructing complex coordinates in the particular case of the conifold ⁢C(T1,1). In Section 4 we extract the complete set of special Killing forms on the Sasaki-Einstein space T1,1. Finally, our conclusions are presented within the last Section.
A natural generalization of conformal Killing vector fields is given by the conformal Killing forms which are sometimes referred as twistor forms or conformal Killing-Yano tensors.

p.text: A conformal Killing-Yano tensor of rank p on a n-dimensional Riemannian manifold (M,g) is a p-form ψ which satisfies

Math.text: (nabla _ X)@(psi) = ((1 / (p + 1)) * X * lrcorner * d * psi - (1 / ((n - p) + 1)) * X ^ *) and d ^ * * psi

p.text: for any vector field X on M.

para.p: Here we used the standard conventions: ∇ is the Levi-Civita connection with respect to the metric g, X* is the 1-form dual to the vector field X, ⌟ is the operator dual to the wedge product and d* is the adjoint of the exterior derivative d.
In component notation, the conformal Killing-Yano tensor equation is given by
We used round brackets to denote symmetrization over the indices within. For =p1 we recover the usual definition of a Killing vector:
If ψ is co-closed in (1), then we obtain the definition of a Killing-Yano tensor [23] which, in component notation, satisfies the equation:

Math.text: (nabla _ [(j])@(psi _ [i1)i2…ip]) = 0.

para.p: A particular class of Killing forms is represented by the special Killing forms:

p.text: A Killing form ψ is said to be a special Killing form if it satisfies for some constant c the additional equation

Math.text: (nabla _ X)@(d * psi) = c * X ^ * and psi

p.text: for any vector field X on M.

para.p: It is worth mentioning the fact that the most known Killing forms are actually special.
There is also a symmetric generalization of the Killing vectors:

p.text: A symmetric tensor K⁢i1⋯ir of rank >r1 satisfying the generalized Killing equation

para.p: The analogue of the conserved quantities associated with Killing vectors is given by the following proposition:

p.text: For any geodesic γ with tangent vector ˙γi

Math.text: Q _ K = K _ (i _ 1 * cdots * i _ r) * (dot@(gamma)) ^ (i _ 1) * cdots * (dot@(gamma)) ^ (i _ r)

para.p: Let us note that there is an important connection between these two generalizations of the Killing vectors. To wit, given two Killing-Yano tensors ψi1,…,ik and σi1,…,ik there is a Stäckel-Killing tensor of rank 2:

Math.text: (K ^ (open-interval@(psi, sigma))) _ (i * j) = psi _ (i * i _ 2 * dots * i _ k) * (sigma _ j) ^ (i _ 2 * dots * i _ k) + sigma _ (i * i _ 2 * dots * i _ k) * (psi _ j) ^ (i _ 2 * dots * i _ k)

para.p: This fact offers a method to generate higher order integrals of motion by identifying the complete set of Killing forms.

p.text: An almost contact structure on a smooth manifold M is a triple (φ,B,η), where φ is a field of endomorphisms of the tangent spaces, B is a vector field and η is a 1-form on M satisfying (see [17])

Math.text: formulae@(varphi ^ 2 = (- I) + eta tensor-product B, eta * B = 1.)

para.p: We remark that many authors also include in the above definition the conditions that =⁢φB0 and =∘ηφ0, although these are deducible from (2) (see [2]).
A Riemannian metric g on M is said to be compatible with the almost contact structure (φ,B,η) if and only if the relation

Math.text: g * open-interval@(varphi * X, varphi * Y) = g * open-interval@(X, Y) - eta * X * eta * Y

para.p: holds for all pairs of vector fields X,Y on M. In this case (φ,B,η,g) is called an almost contact metric structure. Moreover, if the Levi-Civita connection ∇ of the metric g satisfies

Math.text: (nabla _ X)@(varphi) * Y = g * open-interval@(X, Y) * B - eta * Y * X

para.p: for all vector fields X,Y on M, then (φ,B,η,g) is said to be a Sasakian structure [2].

It is also important to note that Sasakian geometry is in fact the odd-dimensional counterpart of Kähler geometry, since a Sasakian structure may be reinterpreted and characterized in terms of the metric cone as follows. The metric cone of a Riemannian manifold (M,g) is the Riemannian manifold =⁢C(M)×(0,∞)M with the metric given by

Math.text: bar@(g) = d * r ^ 2 + r ^ 2 * g

para.p: where r is a coordinate on (0,∞). Then M is a Sasaki manifold if and only if its metric cone ⁢C(M) is Kähler [3]. We note that the one form η extends to a one form on ⁢C(M) by =⁢η(X)⁢12¯g(B,X) and M is identified with the subset =r1 of ⁢C(M). In particular, the cone ⁢C(M) is equipped with an integrable complex structure J defined by

Math.text: formulae@(J * r * partial-differential _ r = B, formulae@(J * Y = varphi * Y - eta * Y * r * partial-differential _ r, Y element-of T * M))

para.p: and a Kähler 2-form ω given by

where =dc⁢i2(-¯∂∂), both J and ω being parallel with respect to the Levi-Civita connection ¯∇ of ¯g. Moreover, M has odd dimension +⁢2n1, where +n1 is the complex dimension of the Kähler cone. Conversely, given any algebraic Kähler orbifold, we can naturally associate to it a quasi-regular Sasakian manifold [3].
An Einstein manifold is a Riemannian manifold (M,g) satisfying the Einstein condition

Math.text: R * i * c _ g = lambda * g

para.p: for some real constant λ, where ⁢Ricg denotes the Ricci tensor of g. Einstein manifolds with =λ0 are called Ricci-flat manifolds. A Sasaki-Einstein manifold is a Riemannian manifold (M,g) that is both Sasaki and Einstein. We note that in the case of Sasaki-Einstein manifolds one always has (3) with the Einstein constant =λ⁢2n. We also remark that Gauss equation relating the curvature of submanifolds to the second fundamental form shows that a Sasaki manifold M is Einstein if and only if the metric cone ⁢C(M) is Kähler Ricci-flat. In particular the Kähler cone of an Sasaki-Einstein manifold has trivial canonical bundle [4, 21]. We note that one of the most familiar example of homogeneous Sasaki-Einstein five-manifold is the space =T1,1×S2S3 endowed with the following metric [11, 5]

Math.text: d * ^ s * ^ T = (1 / 6) * (d * _ (^ theta) + (^ sine)@(_ theta * d * _ (^ phi)) + d * _ (^ theta) + (^ sine)@(_ theta * d * _ (^ phi))) + (1 / 9) * ^ (d * psi + cosine@(_ theta * d * _ phi) + cosine@(_ theta * d * _ phi))

para.p: A toric Sasaki manifold M is a Sasaki manifold whose Kähler cone ⁢C(M) is a toric Kähler manifold [7]. In particular, a five-dimensional toric Sasaki-Einstein manifold is a Sasaki-Einstein manifold with three ⁢U(1) isometries: =GT3. In this case one can construct canonical coordinates based on the symplectic geometry of the cone ⁢C(M) and specify the Sasaki-Einstein structure in terms of toric data together with a single function G, a symplectic potential, on the three-dimensional image of the momentum map [15]. It is known that one of the simplest example of a toric non-orbifold singularity is the conifold ⁢C(T1,1), i.e. the Calabi-Yau cone over T1,1.

On the other hand, according to Semmelman [18], there is a correspondence between special Killing forms defined on the Sasaki-Einstein manifold M and the parallel forms defined on the metric cone ⁢C(M). More exactly, a p-dimensional differential form Ψ is a special Killing form on M if and only if the corresponding form

Math.text: Psi _ (c * o * n * e) assign (r ^ p * d * r and Psi) + (r ^ (p + 1) / (p + 1)) * d * Psi

para.p: is parallel on ⁢C(M).
In particular, on a five-dimensional Sasaki manifold M with the Reeb vector field B and 1-form :=ηB∗, there are the following two special Killing forms:

Math.text: formulae@(Psi _ 1 = eta and d * eta, Psi _ 2 = eta and (d * eta) ^ 2)

para.p: Besides these Killing forms, there are two closed conformal Killing forms, also called ∗-Killing forms, given by

Math.text: formulae@(Phi _ 1 = d * eta, Phi _ 2 = (d * eta) ^ 2)

para.p: Moreover, in the case of the Calabi-Yau cone ⁢C(M) it follows that we have two additional Killing forms on M connected with the additional parallel forms of the cone given by the holomorphic complex volume form Ω of ⁢C(M) and its conjugate [18].

subsection.title: 2.3Symplectic and complex coordinates on toric manifolds

para.p: Let us consider a toric Sasaki-Einstein manifold. In the spirit of [1] we use in our further considerations the symplectic (action-angle) coordinates (yi,Φi); here the angular coordinates Φi will generate the toric action. The yi coordinates are obtained using the momentum map =μ⁢12r2η, with the correspondence

Math.text: y ^ i = mu * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(Phi ^ i))

para.p: The Kähler form ω can be written in the simple manner [1, 13]

Math.text: omega = d * y ^ i and d * Phi ^ i

para.p: In turn, the corresponding Kähler metric on the cone ⁢C(M) is constructed using the symplectic potential G, which is a strictly convex function =G⁢G(y) of homogeneous degree -1 in y [13, 1]. We get

Math.text: d * s ^ 2 = G _ (i * j) * d * y ^ i * d * y ^ j + G ^ (i * j) * d * Phi ^ i * d * Phi ^ j

para.p: where the metric coefficients are computed

Math.text: G _ (i * j) = (partial-differential ^ 2)@(G) / (partial-differential@(y ^ i) * partial-differential@(y ^ j))

para.p: with =(G⁢ij)(G⁢ij)-1.
The complex structure J can be described using the above symplectic coordinates metric coefficients, namely
Now we return to the construction of the symplectic potential G.

A classical result of Delzant associates to any Delzant polytope ∈PRn a close connected symplectic manifold M, together with a Hamiltonian Tn action on the manifold, showing that the polytope turns out to be the image of the momentum map, =P⁢μ(M). We remaind that a Delzant polytope is a convex polytope such that there are n edges meeting at each vertex, each edge meeting at the vertex is of form +1⁢tui, where ∈uiZn, and {ui} can be chosen to form a basis in Zn.
A Delzant polytope can be described by the inequalities

Math.text: l _ A * y assign list@(y, v _ A) >= 0 * [, for ] * 1 less= A less= d

para.p: where {vA} are inward pointing normal vectors to the facets of the polytope, d is the number of facets [1, 7].

p.text: In the case of the Calabi-Yau cone we take ⁢C(M) to be Gorenstein which is a necessary condition to admit a Ricci-flat Kähler metric and M to admit a Sasaki-Einstein metric. For affine toric varieties it is well-known that ⁢C(M) being Gorenstein is equivalent to the existence of a basis for the torus Tn for which

Math.text: v _ i = open-interval@(+ 1, w _ i)

para.p: If B is the Reeb vector field, let us point out the following relation which links this geometric object to the metric coefficients

Math.text: B _ i = 2 * G _ (i * j) * y ^ j

para.p: Now let us also define the affine function :=lB⟨B,⋅⟩, and :=l∞⟨∑AvA,⋅⟩. Then, the symplectic potential G can be written in terms of the toric data [1, 7]

Math.text: G = G ^ (c * a * n) + G ^ B + h

para.p: where

Math.text: G ^ (c * a * n) = (1 / 2) * (sum _ A)@(l _ A * y * logarithm@(l _ A) * y)
G ^ (c * a * n)
(1 / 2) * (sum _ A)@(l _ A * y * logarithm@(l _ A) * y)
G ^ B = (1 / 2) * l _ B * y * logarithm@(l _ B) * y - (1 / 2) * l _ infinity * y * logarithm@(l _ infinity) * y
G ^ B
(1 / 2) * l _ B * y * logarithm@(l _ B) * y - (1 / 2) * l _ infinity * y * logarithm@(l _ infinity) * y

para.p: and h is a homogeneous function of degree 1 in variables y. In the general case, as G needs to satisfy the Monge-Ampère equation, the function h is added.

For a complete determination of the symplectic potential G it is necessary to compute the Reeb vector B and the function h. There are two known different algebraic procedures to extract the components of the Reeb vector from the toric data. According to the AdS/CFT correspondence the volume of the Sasaki-Einstein space corresponds to the central charge of the dual conformal field theory. The first procedure is based on the maximization of the central charge (a-maximization) [9] used in connection with the computation of the Weyl anomaly in 4-dimensional field theory. The second one is known as volume minimization (or Z-minimization) [13].

The symplectic potential allow us to pass to the coordinate patch (xi,Φi) obtained from complex coordinates :=zi+xi⁢iΦi, with :=i-1; this is possible via the Legendre transform which relates the symplectic potential G and the Kähler potential F
Consequently F and G are Legendre dual to each other

Math.text: F * x + G * y = (sum _ j)@((partial-differential@(F) / partial-differential@(x ^ j)) * (partial-differential@(G) / partial-differential@(y ^ i)))

para.p: and

Math.text: formulae@(x ^ i = partial-differential@(G) / partial-differential@(y ^ i), [ ] * y ^ i = partial-differential@(F) / partial-differential@(x ^ i))

para.p: The metric structure is now written in the following manner

Math.text: d * s ^ 2 = F _ (i * j) * d * x ^ i * d * x ^ j + F _ (i * j) * d * Phi ^ i * d * Phi ^ j

para.p: where the metric coefficients are again obtained using the Hessian of the Kähler potential F, i.e.

Math.text: F _ (i * j) = (partial-differential ^ 2)@(F) / (partial-differential@(x ^ i) * partial-differential@(x ^ j))

para.p: Note also that =(F⁢ij)(G⁢ij) [1].
With respect to the coordinates (xi,Φi), the Kähler form is

Math.text: omega = Array[[0, F _ (i * j)], [- F _ (i * j), 0]]

para.p: We use in the following the fact that the Calabi-Yau metric cone is Ricci flat. From the classical formula

Math.text: rho = - i * partial-differential@(bar@(partial-differential) * logarithm) * determinant@(F _ (i * j))

para.p: we get

Math.text: determinant@(G _ (i * j)) = exponential@(2 * gamma _ i * (partial-differential@(G) / partial-differential@(y ^ i)) - c)

para.p: with constants γi, and c. Using (9)-(10), we are able to express the coordinates xi and the metric coefficients G⁢ij

Math.text: formulae@(^ x = partial-differential@(G) / partial-differential@(y ^ i) = (((1 / 2) * (_ sum)@(^ (_ v) * logarithm@(_ l) * y) + (1 / 2) * ^ B * (1 + logarithm@(_ l) * y)) - (1 / 2) * (_ sum)@(^ (_ v) * logarithm@(_ l) * y)) + _ lambda, _ G = ((1 / 2) * (_ sum)@(((v _ A) ^ i * (v _ A) ^ j) / (l _ A * y)) + (1 / 2) * ((B _ i * B _ j) / (l _ B * y))) - (1 / 2) * ((sum _ A)@((v _ A) ^ i * (sum _ A)@((v _ A) ^ j)) / (l _ infinity * y)))

para.p: Now, as the metric has to be smooth, from (11) it turns out that [15]
and

Math.text: determinant@(F _ (i * j)) = exponential@(2 * x ^ 1 + c)

para.p: If Vol is the volume form on the metric cone, then the holomorphic volume form Ω satisfies

Math.text: Vol = (i ^ (n + 1) / 2 ^ (n + 1)) * (- 1) ^ ((n * (n + 1)) / 2) * Omega and bar@(Omega) = (1 / (n + 1)factorial) * omega ^ (n + 1)

para.p: Then, eventually ignoring the multiplicative constant, in complex coordinates Ω can be written as [13]

As Ω is parallel, it is also closed. Then we can fix the phase α to be Φ1, and we obtain the following simple formula for the holomorphic volume form, which motivates the interest for complex (and consequently, symplectic) coordinates
Employing the above relation, in the next sections we show that it is possible to extract the special Killing forms on manifolds of Sasaki-Einstein type.
Throughout this section we introduce complex coordinates on ⁢C(T1,1) using the classical procedure exposed above.
We start out by considering the global defined contact 1-form

Math.text: eta = (1 / 3) * (d * psi + cosine@(theta _ 1 * d * phi _ 1) + cosine@(theta _ 2 * d * phi _ 2))

para.p: This form allows us to construct on ⁢C(T1,1) the symplectic form (see e.g. [11])

Math.text: omega = ((- (r ^ 2 / 6) * (((sine@(_ theta * d * _ theta) and d * _ phi) + sine@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi)) + (1 / 3) * r * d * r) and (d * psi + cosine@(_ theta * d * _ phi) + cosine@(_ theta * d * _ phi))

para.p: Furthermore, if we employ the basis [11] for an effectively acting T3 action

Math.text: formulae@(_ e = partial-differential / partial-differential@(phi _ 1) + (1 / 2) * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(nu)), formulae@(_ e = partial-differential / partial-differential@(phi _ 2) + (1 / 2) * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(nu)), _ e = partial-differential / partial-differential@(nu)))

para.p: where =⁢2νψ, then, considering action coordinates associated with this basis, we get the momentum map using (7) (see also [11])
The Reeb vector field B has the form

Math.text: B = 3 * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(psi)) = (3 / 2) * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(nu))

para.p: and is easy to see that =⁢η(B)1.
Now let us consider the ‘‘inward pointing’’ primitive normal vectors to the cone

Math.text: formulae@((v _ 1) ^ prime = list@(- 1, 0, 1), formulae@((v _ 2) ^ prime = list@(0, - 1, 1), formulae@((v _ 3) ^ prime = list@(1, 0, 0), (v _ 4) ^ prime = list@(0, 1, 0))))

para.p: We apply a ⁢SL(3;Z) transformation T (see also [11])
to bring the vectors =vi⁢Tvi′ in the form (8) [15]

Math.text: formulae@(v _ 1 = list@(1, 1, 1), formulae@(v _ 2 = list@(1, 0, 1), formulae@(v _ 3 = list@(1, 0, 0), v _ 4 = list@(1, 1, 0))))

para.p: According to the above transformation we obtain the new basis

Math.text: formulae@(^ (_ e) = partial-differential / partial-differential@(phi _ 1) + (1 / 2) * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(nu)), formulae@(^ (_ e) = partial-differential / partial-differential@(phi _ 2) - partial-differential / partial-differential@(phi _ 1), ^ (_ e) = - partial-differential / partial-differential@(phi _ 1) - partial-differential / partial-differential@(phi _ 2)))

para.p: where :=ei′⁢eiT-1.
We consider the new angle coordinates
and it is easy to check that

Math.text: (e _ i) ^ prime = partial-differential / partial-differential@(Phi ^ i)

para.p: In this new basis, applying (7), the momentum map becomes:

Math.text: mu ^ prime = y = vector@((1 / 6) * r ^ 2 * (cosine@(theta _ 1) + 1), (1 / 6) * r ^ 2 * (cosine@(theta _ 2) - cosine@(theta _ 1)), - (1 / 6) * r ^ 2 * (cosine@(theta _ 1) + cosine@(theta _ 2)))

para.p: This way we end up with the symplectic action-angle coordinates (yi, Φi), for 1≤i≤3.

Now, in order to introduce the complex coordinates on conifold we need the symplectic potential G. In the particular case of the conifold T1,1, the sum +G⁢canGB is already a solution of the Monge-Ampère equation. Consequently the function h is not needed anymore, and the equations (9)-(10) simplify as (see e.g. [15])

Math.text: G = G ^ (c * a * n) + G ^ B

para.p: where

Math.text: G ^ (c * a * n) = ((sum _ (A = 1)) ^ 4)@((1 / 2) * list@(v _ A, y) * logarithm@(v _ A, y))

para.p: and

Math.text: G ^ B = (1 / 2) * list@(B, y) * logarithm@(B, y) - (1 / 2) * list@(B ^ (c * a * n), y) * logarithm@(B ^ (c * a * n), y)

para.p: In the above relation the vectors vA are just (15) and
Concerning the Reeb vector field on T1,1 (14) written in the new basis {ei′} (16), it has the components
consistent with the determination from toric data using Z-minimization [9] or a-maximization [13].
We construct complex coordinates using (18) and the Legendre transform

Math.text: ^ x@=@partial-differential@(G) / partial-differential@(y ^ i)@=@1 / 2@^ (_ sum)@^ (_ v)@logarithm@less@_ v@,@y@>@+@1 / 2@^ B@logarithm@less@B@,@>@+@1 / 2@^ B@-@1 / 2@^ (@^ B@)@logarithm@less@^ B@,@y@>@[]

para.p: But it is easy to see that

Math.text: formulae@((^ (_ sum))@(^ (_ v) * logarithm) less _ v, formulae@(y >= (8 * logarithm@(r) + 2 * logarithm@(sine@(_ theta)) + 2 * logarithm@(sine@(_ theta))) - 4 * logarithm@(2) - 4 * logarithm@(3), formulae@((^ (_ sum))@(^ (_ v) * logarithm) less _ v, formulae@(y >= (4 * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(1 - cosine@(_ theta)) + logarithm@(1 + cosine@(_ theta))) - 2 * logarithm@(2) - 2 * logarithm@(3), formulae@((^ (_ sum))@(^ (_ v) * logarithm) less _ v, formulae@(y >= (4 * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(1 - cosine@(_ theta)) + logarithm@(1 - cosine@(_ theta))) - 2 * logarithm@(2) - 2 * logarithm@(3), formulae@(logarithm less B, formulae@(y >= 2 * logarithm@(r) - logarithm@(2), formulae@(logarithm less ^ B, y >= (2 * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(2)) - logarithm@(3.))))))))))

para.p: Using now (19) and basic trigonometric formulas, we derive

Math.tex: \begin{split}\displaystyle x^{1}&\displaystyle=3\log r+\log\sin\theta_{1}+\log% \sin\theta_{2}+\frac{3}{2}-\frac{11}{2}\log 2\,,\\ \displaystyle x^{2}&\displaystyle=\frac{3}{2}\log r+\log\sin\frac{\theta_{1}}{% 2}+\log\cos\frac{\theta_{2}}{2}+\frac{3}{4}-\frac{11}{4}\log 2\,,\\ \displaystyle x^{3}&\displaystyle=\frac{3}{2}\log r+\log\sin\frac{\theta_{1}}{% 2}+\log\sin\frac{\theta_{2}}{2}\frac{3}{4}-\frac{11}{4}\log 2\,.\end{split}
Math.text: formulae@(^ x = (3 * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(sine@(_ theta)) + logarithm@(sine@(_ theta)) + 3 / 2) - (11 / 2) * logarithm@(2), formulae@(^ x = ((3 / 2) * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(sine@(theta _ 1 / 2)) + logarithm@(cosine@(theta _ 2 / 2)) + 3 / 4) - (11 / 4) * logarithm@(2), ^ x = ((3 / 2) * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(sine@(theta _ 1 / 2)) + logarithm@(sine@((theta _ 2 / 2) * (3 / 4)))) - (11 / 4) * logarithm@(2.)))

para.p: In the sequel, for the sake of simplicity we will ignore the additive constants. Therefore, in accordance with [13] we can introduce on conifold ⁢C(T1,1) the following patch of complex coordinates

Math.tex: \begin{split}\displaystyle z^{1}&\displaystyle=3\log r+\log\sin\theta_{1}+\log% \sin\theta_{2}+\mathrm{i}\psi,\\ \displaystyle z^{2}&\displaystyle=\frac{3}{2}\log r+\log\sin\frac{\theta_{1}}{% 2}+\log\cos\frac{\theta_{2}}{2}\\ &\displaystyle+\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}(\psi+\phi_{1}+\phi_{2}),\\ \displaystyle z^{3}&\displaystyle=\frac{3}{2}\log r+\log\sin\frac{\theta_{1}}{% 2}+\log\sin\frac{\theta_{2}}{2}\\ &\displaystyle+\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}(\psi-\phi_{1}-\phi_{2})\,.\end{split}
Math.text: formulae@(^ z = 3 * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(sine@(_ theta)) + logarithm@(sine@(_ theta)) + i * psi, formulae@(^ z = (3 / 2) * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(sine@(theta _ 1 / 2)) + logarithm@(cosine@(theta _ 2 / 2)) + (i / 2) * (psi + _ phi + _ phi), ^ z = (3 / 2) * logarithm@(r) + logarithm@(sine@(theta _ 1 / 2)) + logarithm@(sine@(theta _ 2 / 2)) + (i / 2) * (psi - _ phi - _ phi)))

para.p: Now, regarding (12), we see that the above coordinates are precisely the necessary ingredient in order to extract the special Killing forms on our homogeneous Sasaki-Einstein manifold.
Applying the above general results, in this section we obtain the complete set of special Killing forms on the manifold T1,1.
First of all, we have to calculate the holomorphic volume form Ω. Starting out with (20), we obtain

Math.text: formulae@(exponential@(^ z) = ^ r * sine@(_ theta) * sine@(_ theta * exponential@(i * psi)), formulae@(d * ^ z = (3 / r) * d * r + _ T, formulae@(d * ^ z = (3 / (2 * r)) * d * r + _ T, d * ^ z = (3 / (2 * r)) * d * r + _ T)))

para.p: where

Math.text: _ T@colon@=@cotangent@_ theta@d@_ theta@+@cotangent@_ theta@d@_ theta@+@i@d@psi@[]@_ T@colon@=@1 / 2@cotangent@theta _ 1 / 2@d@_ theta@-@1 / 2@tangent@theta _ 2 / 2@d@_ theta@+@i / 2@(@d@psi@-@d@_ phi@+@d@_ phi@)@[]@_ T@colon@=@1 / 2@cotangent@theta _ 1 / 2@d@_ theta@+@1 / 2@cotangent@theta _ 2 / 2@d@_ theta@+@i / 2@(@d@psi@-@d@_ phi@-@d@_ phi@)@[]

para.p: Now we calculate the holomorphic volume form (see e.g. [13])

Math.text: Omega = exponential@(^ z) * d * ^ z and d * ^ z and d * ^ z = exponential@(^ z) * ((3 / r) * d * r + _ T) and ((3 / (2 * r)) * d * r + _ T) and ((3 / (2 * r)) * d * r + _ T)

para.p: In our particular framework the equation (4) becomes

Math.text: Omega = (r ^ 2 * d * r and Psi) + (r ^ 3 / 3) * d * Psi

para.p: In order to extract Ψ we have to keep the trace of the differential form ⁢dr in the above equation. We clearly get

Math.text: Psi = 3 * sine@(theta _ 1) * sine@(theta _ 2 * exponential@(i * psi)) * ((((((1 / 4) * T _ 2 and T _ 3) - (1 / 2) * T _ 1) and T _ 3) + (1 / 2) * T _ 1) and T _ 2)

para.p: We calculate the above wedge products using (21). For the first wedge product in (22), after calculations we get

Math.tex: \begin{split}\displaystyle T_{2}\wedge T_{3}&\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\cot% \frac{\theta_{1}}{2}\frac{1}{\sin\theta_{2}}d\theta_{1}\wedge d\theta_{2}-% \frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\frac{\theta_{1}}{2}d\theta_{1}\wedge d\phi_{2}\\ &\displaystyle\ -\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\frac{1}{\sin\theta_{2}}d\theta_{2}\wedge d% \psi+\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\frac{1}{\sin\theta_{2}}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{1}-% \frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{2}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{2}\\ &\displaystyle\ -\frac{1}{2}d\phi_{1}\wedge d\phi_{2}+\frac{1}{2}d\psi\wedge d% \phi_{2}\,.\end{split}
Math.text: _ T and _ T = (((((((((((((1 / 2) * cotangent@((theta _ 1 / 2) * (1 / sine@(theta _ 2)) * d * _ theta) and d * _ theta) - (i / 2) * cotangent@((theta _ 1 / 2) * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - (i / 2) * (1 / sine@(theta _ 2)) * d * _ theta) and d * psi) + (i / 2) * (1 / sine@(theta _ 2)) * d * _ theta) and d * _ phi) - (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - (1 / 2) * d * _ phi) and d * _ phi) + (1 / 2) * d * psi) and d * _ phi

para.p: For the second product we obtain

Math.tex: \begin{split}\displaystyle T_{1}\wedge T_{3}&\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}(\cot% \theta_{1}\cot\frac{\theta_{2}}{2}-\cot\theta_{2}\cot\frac{\theta_{1}}{2})d% \theta_{1}\wedge d\theta_{2}-\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\frac{1}{\sin\theta_{1}}d% \theta_{1}\wedge d\psi\\ &\displaystyle-\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{1}d\theta_{1}\wedge d\phi_{1}-% \frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{1}d\theta_{1}\wedge d\phi_{2}-\frac{\mathrm{i}% }{2}\frac{1}{\sin\theta_{2}}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\psi\\ &\displaystyle-\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{2}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{1}-% \frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{2}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{2}+\frac{1}{2}d\psi% \wedge d\phi_{1}+\frac{1}{2}d\psi\wedge d\phi_{2}\,.\end{split}
Math.text: _ T and _ T = (((((((((((((((((1 / 2) * (cotangent@(_ theta) * cotangent@(theta _ 2 / 2) - cotangent@(_ theta) * cotangent@(theta _ 1 / 2)) * d * _ theta and d * _ theta) - (i / 2) * (1 / sine@(theta _ 1)) * d * _ theta) and d * psi) - (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - (i / 2) * (1 / sine@(theta _ 2)) * d * _ theta) and d * psi) - (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) + (1 / 2) * d * psi) and d * _ phi) + (1 / 2) * d * psi) and d * _ phi

para.p: Finally, for the last product we get

Math.tex: \begin{split}\displaystyle T_{1}\wedge T_{2}&\displaystyle=-\frac{1}{2}(\cot% \theta_{1}\tan\frac{\theta_{2}}{2}-\cot\theta_{2}\cot\frac{\theta_{1}}{2})d% \theta_{1}\wedge d\theta_{2}-\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\frac{1}{\sin\theta_{1}}d% \theta_{1}\wedge d\psi\\ &\displaystyle\ \ -\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{1}d\theta_{1}\wedge d\phi_{% 1}+\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{1}d\theta_{1}\wedge d\phi_{2}+\frac{\mathrm% {i}}{2}\frac{1}{\sin\theta_{2}}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\psi\\ &\displaystyle\ -\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{2}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{1}% +\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\cot\theta_{2}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{2}+\frac{1}{2}d% \psi\wedge d\phi_{1}-\frac{1}{2}d\psi\wedge d\phi_{2}\,.\end{split}
Math.text: _ T and _ T = (((((((((((((((((- (1 / 2) * (cotangent@(_ theta) * tangent@(theta _ 2 / 2) - cotangent@(_ theta) * cotangent@(theta _ 1 / 2)) * d * _ theta) and d * _ theta) - (i / 2) * (1 / sine@(theta _ 1)) * d * _ theta) and d * psi) - (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) + (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) + (i / 2) * (1 / sine@(theta _ 2)) * d * _ theta) and d * psi) - (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) + (i / 2) * cotangent@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) + (1 / 2) * d * psi) and d * _ phi) - (1 / 2) * d * psi) and d * _ phi

para.p: Now we plug (23)-(25) in (22) and we end up with the simple formula bellow for the special complex Killing form (in what follows we ignore the multiplicative constants)

Math.text: Psi = exponential@(i * psi) * list@(((2 * d * _ theta and d * _ theta) - 2 * i * sine@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ theta, (((+ 2 * i * sine@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - 2 * sine@(_ theta) * sine@(_ theta * d * _ phi)) and d * _ phi)

para.p: From here, we can easily derive the real special Killing forms computing the real and imaginary part of Ψ:

Math.text: real-part@(Psi) = ((((((cosine@(psi * d * _ theta) and d * _ theta) + sine@(_ theta) * sine@(psi * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - sine@(_ theta) * sine@(psi * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - sine@(_ theta) * sine@(_ theta) * cosine@(psi * d * _ phi)) and d * _ phi

imaginary-part@(Psi) = ((((((sine@(psi * d * _ theta) and d * _ theta) - sine@(_ theta) * cosine@(psi * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) + sine@(_ theta) * cosine@(psi * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi) - sine@(_ theta) * sine@(_ theta) * sine@(psi * d * _ phi)) and d * _ phi

para.p: Finally, we calculate the Killing forms Φ1 and Φ2 (6), Ψ1 and Ψ2 (5) using the contact 1-form η (13). We obtain

Math.text: Phi _ 1 = d * eta = - (1 / 3) * (((sine@(theta _ 1 * d * theta _ 1) and d * phi _ 1) + sine@(theta _ 2 * d * theta _ 2)) and d * phi _ 2)
Phi _ 2 = (d * eta) ^ 2 = (- (2 / 9) * sine@(theta _ 1) * sine@(theta _ 2 * d * theta _ 1)) and d * theta _ 2 and d * phi _ 1 and d * phi _ 2

para.p: and respectively

Math.tex: \begin{split}\displaystyle\Psi_{1}=&\displaystyle\eta\wedge d\eta=\frac{1}{9}(% \sin\theta_{1}d\psi\wedge d\theta_{1}\wedge d\phi_{1}+\sin\theta_{2}d\psi% \wedge d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{2}\\ &\displaystyle-\cos\theta_{1}\sin\theta_{2}d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_{1}\wedge d% \phi_{2}+\cos\theta_{2}\sin\theta_{1}d\theta_{1}\wedge d\phi_{1}\wedge d\phi_{% 2})\,,\\ \displaystyle\Psi_{2}=&\displaystyle\eta\wedge(d\eta)^{2}=-\frac{2}{27}\sin% \theta_{1}\sin\theta_{2}d\psi\wedge d\theta_{1}\wedge d\theta_{2}\wedge d\phi_% {1}\wedge d\phi_{2}\,.\end{split}
Math.text: formulae@(_ Psi = eta and d * eta = (1 / 9) * (((((((sine@(_ theta * d * psi) and d * _ theta and d * _ phi) + sine@(_ theta * d * psi)) and d * _ theta and d * _ phi) - cosine@(_ theta) * sine@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi and d * _ phi) + cosine@(_ theta) * sine@(_ theta * d * _ theta)) and d * _ phi and d * _ phi), _ Psi = eta and ^ (d * eta) = (- (2 / 27) * sine@(_ theta) * sine@(_ theta * d * psi)) and d * _ theta and d * _ theta and d * _ phi and d * _ phi)

para.p: The significance of the present work relies on unquestionable relevance of conformal Killing-Yano tensors in both mathematics and physics. It is known that it is a very difficult problem to find solutions of the conformal Killing-Yano equations on arbitrary Riemannian manifolds, but fortunately, in the case of spaces endowed with remarkable geometrical structures the explicit construction of the Killing forms is permitted.

In this paper we have obtained the complete set of special Killing forms on the five-dimensional Sasaki-Einstein space T1,1 with an approach based on the interplay between symplectic and complex coordinates on Kähler toric manifolds. On the other hand, concerning the potential of the present paper, as a lot of non-trivial examples of toric Sasaki-Einstein manifolds occurs in the recent literature (see, e.g., [6, 12, 19]), it is both natural and useful to extend the present work to other spaces of interest. In fact, using toric geometry many examples of Sasaki-Einstein manifolds can be constructed, and these spaces are a good testing ground for the predictions of the AdS/CFT correspondence [14].

U. Semmelmann, Conformal Killing forms on Riemannian manifolds, Math. Z. 245 (2003) 503–527; arXiv:math.DG/0206117.

C. van Coevering, Some examples of toric Sasaki-Einstein manifolds, Riemannian topology and geometric structures on manifolds, 185–232, Progr. Math. 271 (2009), Birkhäuser Boston, Boston, MA; arXiv:math/0703501.
